comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: Her name was Evelyn Nesbit. She was a chorus girl who had relationships with Stanford White, John Barrymore, & the rather unstable Mr. Thaw. During a performance one night, Thaw shot Stanford White in the face three times, killing him instantly. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Nesbit

comment._content: bwanderson, The LoC URL you used was a temporary one created during searches. The URL near the bottom of the page in the Digital ID is the best thing to use to link back to an individual picture. LoC has several portraits of Evelyn Nesbit. See lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/p?pp/PPALL:@FIELD(SUBJ+@band...

comment.author: 80278590@N00

comment.author: 86544988@N00
comment._content: Wonderful photo, I wish I knew something about the moment it was taken. So many great little visual details

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: This negative has a stamp with the date 6/22/1? with my best guess (looking at the high-res image) of it being 1912 or 1915. A search of the NYT finds that this couple was in the news a lot during this period. June, 1912 had hearings as to Harry Thaw's sanity, with Evelyn taking the stand. This outfit seems appropriate for a court appearance and she's outside a formal building. See, for example, June 22, 1912, Saturday, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C00E4DE113AE633A... "EVELYN THAW WON'T TELL THE OLD STORY; Thaw Hid Behind Her Skirts, She Says, "in His Two Dirty Murder Trials," but Won't Now." There were also sanity hearings in June/July 1915, but Evelyn didn't take the stand after first evading the subpoena and then claiming a nervous breakdown. After being arrested, she was then excused by the judge. Meanwhile I notice that a biography was published this year. See www.nytimes.com/2008/06/01/books/review/Calhoun-t.html?scp=2

comment.author: 63817448@N00
comment._content:
I am a descendent of Harry K Thaw. The book Ragtime is a must read for anyone interested in this story, as well as a good PBS documentary featured on The American Experience entitled "Murder of the Century". There is a lot of Thaw history to be found in the Pittsburgh, PA area as well. 

Harry also wrote a book about Evelyn and the trial called "The Traitor" which capitalized on his newfound fame as a sort of folk hero (as White was portrayted to be the evil one), but it is terribly written. Still, if you can find it, it is interesting to read how his unstable mind worked and perceived things.

comment.author: 12683585@N05
comment._content:
Evelyn Nesbit, the young woman in the image, was a major celebrity in her day.  She started modeling in her early teens for many prominent artists, went on to become one of the famous "Gibson Girls", and also launched her own acting career. 

 At the very young age of 17, she was 'seduced' (today we'd call this rape) by highly-known and influential architect, Stanford White, of the architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White.  For many years thereafter, Nesbit, her mother, and her brother were the beneficiaries of financial support from White.  Nesbit eventually married multi-millionaire, unstable and violent, Harry Thaw.  Thaw had been obsessed for many years with architect S White, believing him to be committed to ruining his (Thaw's) reputation.  When Nesbit revealed to Thaw (who himself had battered and assaulted her on occasions), Thaw became determined to kill S White.  This he did, in public, shooting White in the face with a pistol, in around, I believe, 1910.  Thaw's trial for the murder of White was very big news at the time, and reported extensively in all papers around the country.  

Thaw was tried twice; during the first trial, a hung jury resulted, during the second, he was found not guilty by reason of temporary insanity and committed to an institution for the insane (from which he later escaped).  

Nesbit was forced to testify at both trials and to repeat lurid and provocative details of her relations (sexual and otherwise) with both men.  After this point, her reputation was irrevocably ruined, and, after being rejected by Thaw's extremely wealthy but cold and bizarre family, she struggled to support herself for the rest of her surprisingly long life:  Nesbit lived until the late 60's.  

Hard to believe a life spanning so much change in American society!

Her face should look familiar:  drawings, painting, prints of all kinds were made of her by many artists and designers throughout her youth, and one can still find these frequently reproduced.  One of the most well-known images of her is the profile drawing in black and white of a young, beautiful woman of the times, her hair piled upon her head and trailing down the back of her neck in a manner that resembles a question mark.  This print was entitled, "The Eternal Question".

comment.author: 100317075@N07
comment._content: The workmanship on this jacket is absolutely amazing.  Most likely created from a nicely woven wool.  The bond buttonholes would have been made by hand.  The times were filled with people who would be our current day "Makers".  Maybe the hat was a "Hack".

comment.author: 100317075@N07
comment._content: The fashion she is wearing could only have been created by her contemporary "Makers" and "Hackers".  I think that hat is a "remix".

comment.author: 12683585@N05
comment._content: @Sue, I'm confused by your comments.  Are you suggesting that the hat Nesbit wears in the original photo is not authentic, but was somehow photoshopped?  Far more elaborate hats were worn in Nesbit's day.  Some used the feathers so heavily of particular bird species that the species were driven to extinction.
